Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Modeling, Monitoring, and Analysis of Spatial Point Patterns for Manufacturing Quality Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) collaborative research award is to establish a series of quality control methodologies on modeling, monitoring, and diagnosis of spatial point patterns. A spatial point pattern is a set of locations randomly distributed within a designated region. It is a natural way to model many critical quality characteristics in various manufacturing processes, such as the surface defects on steel bars, slabs and semiconductor wafer, and the distribution of reinforce particles in composite materials. The research approach is in three focus areas: (i) Modeling and monitoring of replicated spatial point patterns by integrating the deterministic point pattern alignment methods and spatial statistics techniques; (ii) Identification of the impacts of covariates on replicated point patterns based on a nonparametric functional regression model; and (iii) Geometric and three-dimension point pattern detection by bringing the Hough Transform method, an interesting computer vision method, into the quality control area.

If successful, the results of this research will provide a novel set of quality control tools to various relevant industries such as steel rolling, semiconductor manufacturing, and composite fabrication. These tools will take advantage of the increasingly available spatial point data and help to significantly improve the process productivity and quality. The close collaboration with OG Technologies in this Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry project will lead to a realistic testbed and quick dissemination of research results among practitioners, as well as initiation of technology transfer. The interdisciplinary nature of this project can provide students the unique opportunity to obtain training in spatial statistics, manufacturing quality control, and computer vision.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A spatial point pattern (SPP) is a set of locations randomly distributed within a designated region. SPP is a natural way to measure many critical quality characteristics in various manufacturing processes, such as the surface defects on steel bars, slabs and semiconductor wafer, and the distribution of reinforce particles in composite materials. Thanks to the information technology revolution, an abundance of data including SPP data is now readily available in many manufacturing processes and systems. Because SPP is a crucial indicator of quality in many processes, it is highly desirable to establish systematic quality control methodologies directly based on modeling and analysis of SPP data. However, the SPP data manifest a complex stochastic process. They are more challenging to analyze than the conventional quality indicators, e.g., dimensional measurement on an assembly. As a result, the SPP-based quality control methodologies are underdeveloped at the current stage. The objective of this project is to establish a series of SPP-based process modeling, monitoring, and diagnosis methodologies.

During the course of the project, many such methodologies have been successfully established. These methodologies can be roughly put into three categories: (1) clustering detection methods for two dimensional (2D) and three dimensional (3D) spatial point patterns; (2) methods for inferring specific geometric patterns or distribution parameters from 2D and 3D spatial point patterns; and (3) statistical change detection methods for temporal event data. The team conducted thorough literature survey on these topics and developed new methodologies to address the research gaps. The advantages of the newly developed methodologies are validated through both simulation and real world data. These results have been summarized in multiple publications in research journals. All these methodologies are very relevant to industrial practices and can help industry to leverage on booming sensing and information technology, and evolve from ad hoc experience-based operations into efficient optimized process control. These methodologies will find broad applications in industries where SPP data play an important role, e.g., steel making, semiconductor manufacturing, composite materials manufacturing, etc.

Besides the intellectual contributions on the new technological development, the interdisciplinary nature of this project provided students the unique opportunity to obtain training in spatial statistics, manufacturing quality control, and computer vision. Through the development of new course materials and research training for participating graduate students, this project made positive impacts on the human resource development as well.
